Hi Joel,

Congratulations to this paper. I read it already, when you put it=
 on arxiv, but great to see that it is now published as a reviewed paper. I=
 think you very nicely demonstrated in the abstract and more concrete model=
 how evolvability can evolve without following any adaptive pressure. I rea=
lly like how Ken and you investigate these fundamental principles in easy t=
o understand simulations. And I am a bit proud to say that the insights of =
this paper are already included in my Artificial Development lecture. :-) 
=

Since you opened a thread for this paper I would like to use this opportun=
ity to ask a question that came to my mind, when I read it the first time:
=

From your simulations, one could falsely conclude that evolvability can an=
d will increase infinitely (which is not a criticism on your paper, because=
 this was not the focus of your study). However, too much evolvability woul=
d decrease the robustness in a genotype-phenotype mapping (e.g. the ability=
 to canalize), which possibly means that evolvability only increases to a c=
ertain extent. Following this perspective, I was wondering whether in actua=
l fact *diversity* is inevitable while evolvability in species will show a =
ceiling effect?

Best,
Martin


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "joel278" <leh=
man.154@...> wrote:
>
> Ken Stanley and I are pleased to annouce our new ar=
ticle, "Evolvability is Inevitable: Increasing Evolvability without the Pre=
ssure to Adapt," which was published today in PLoS ONE. The paper can be vi=
ewed at: 
> 
> http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0062186
> 
> The art=
icle applies both abstract simulations and neuroevolution to explore a non-=
adaptive explanation for increasing evolvability in nature. Interestingy, u=
nderstanding evolvability (the capacity to further evolve) might lead not o=
nly to better understanding how complex organisms evolve in nature, but may=
 also provide insight into how to design evolutionary algorithms that are b=
etter able to evolve complex artifacts.
> 
> Most existing theories for evo=
lvability increase depend upon particular selective scenarios, such as a sp=
ecies surviving through constantly changing environments. However, the insi=
ght in the article is that evolvability can instead arise spontaneously wit=
hout natural selection acting at all. The main idea is that if evolvability=
 is heritable, then evolvable organisms separate themselves naturally from =
less evolvable organisms over time simply by their children becoming increa=
singly diverse and thereby spreading further through the space of possible =
phenotypes. That is, the space of phenotypes itself can act like a filter t=
hat distinguishes evolvability.
> 
> In this way, when novel phenotypes app=
ear in the future, they are most likely descendents of those that were evol=
vable in the past. The result is that evolvable species accumulate over tim=
e even without selective pressure. This idea is supported by a variety of s=
imulations where evolvability increases without any pressure for organisms =
to out-compete each other.
> 
> Those familiar with novelty search will not=
ice some conceptual parallels with Ken's and my previous work on searching =
without objectives. Like novelty search, the proposed non-adaptive hypothes=
is for evolvability may invite some controversy because adaptive explanatio=
ns for evolvability are intuitive and widely-held. For example, researchers=
 often worry about what kind of selective pressure will lead to evolvabilit=
y, even in discussions in this group. One implication of this work could be=
 that such worrying is unwarranted because the best way to get evolvability=
 may sometimes be to stop trying to select for it. In any case, despite any=
 potential controversy, we hope that this alternate perspective leads to co=
nstructive discussion and demonstrates the need to question the assumption =
that evolvability requires particular selective scenarios for it to increas=
e.
> 
> Joel
>
